title: Effect of adding a creditor after discharge
question: I filed a Chapter 7 bankruptcy in August 2010. My debts have been discharged a week ago, but the case has not been closed yet.
answers:
Both of the above answers are correct, and you may need to work quickly to file an amendment to your bankruptcy petition before the case closes. However, any and all executory contracts (that is, contracts in which the parties have not fully performed as required) must also be listed on schedule G, as instructed on that form. The contract itself can be accepted or rejected. While you are amending the contract you should also amend schedule G.

Bankruptcy requires review of your entire financial situation including all debts, income and assets. I highly recommend that you retain an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your jurisdiction to guide you through the complexities of bankruptcy law and procedure.

As long as your case is not closed, you can add the creditor on to your bankruptcy by filing an amendment & paying the filing fee of $26. Once your case closes, that right vanishes!

Of course, you will need to serve the creditor with notice of your bankruptcy. There are documents that must be filed to substantiate service of the notice, so don't overlook that responsibility. If your case has any assets to distribute to your creditors, this creditor will need to have the opportunity to file a claim and get a share of the pie.

Hope this perspective helps & good luck!

If your case was a "no asset" chapter 7 case (i.e. no assets were liquidated and/or distributed to creditors) then the debt to the unlisted creditor was discharged along with the other debts.

The case that provides this is In re Beezley, 994 F.2d 1433 (9th Cir. 1993).

If that creditor has a basis to challenge the discharge of their debt (e.g. because it was incurred through fraud), then they do have the ability to seek permission from the court to late-file a complaint objecting to discharge. But otherwise, the debt was discharged and you do not need to amend to add anything. I would mail them a copy of your discharge notice, however, just to give them some notice.

Mark J. Markus, Attorney at Law
